profileText: A Delegate from New Jersey; born in Philadelphia, Pa., March 22, 1731; attended the common schools; studied law; was admitted to the New Jersey bar in 1753 and practiced in the courts of Pennsylvania and New Jersey, with residence in Burlington County, N.J.; member of the State general assembly 1772-1775; member of the committee of correspondence for Burlington County in 1774 and 1775; Member of the Continental Congress from July 23, 1774, until his resignation effective November 22, 1775; appointed chief justice of the supreme court of New Jersey on November 20, 1789, and served until his death in Burlington, N.J., January 4, 1803; interment in Friends' Burial Ground.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Kinsey, James. A Bill in the Chancery of New-Jersey, at the Suit of Samuel Smith, Esq. One of the Treasurers of New-Jersey, Against Archibald Kennedy, Esq. and Others. Burlington [N.J.]: Printed by Isaac Collins, 1773.

researchRecord.name: 1774, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A note from James Kinsey to an unidentified recipient dated March 14, 1774.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1786, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from James Kinsey to Robert Morris written on December 19, 1786. In the letter, James Kinsey and his brothers, James and Thomas, assign to Robert Morris the ground rent paid to them by Joshua Byrne. The deed from the Kinseys to Byrne, 1762 May 26, is on the verso.

researchRecord.name: In the Parker Family Papers, ca. 1676-1946, 7 linear feet.
In the John Gilmary Shea papers, 26 boxes.
researchRecord.description: Collection includes ADS signed by James Kinsey, with references to John Pope and Edward Thomas.
